channel.title: Comments on: Eclipse / Javadoc tip of the day

item.title: By: Paul Withers
item.dc:creator: Paul Withers
item.description: <p>It's here http://www.intec.co.uk/generating-javadocs-for-xpages-applications/<br />You still have to create from the ODP rather than the NSF, but that's no huge problem.<br />There are also slides covering it from a recent session at DanNotes on slideshare http://www.slideshare.net/mobile/paulswithers1/beyond-domino-designer</p>
item.content:encoded:
It’s here http://www.intec.co.uk/generating-javadocs-for-xpages-applications/
You still have to create from the ODP rather than the NSF, but that’s no huge problem.
There are also slides covering it from a recent session at DanNotes on slideshare http://www.slideshare.net/mobile/paulswithers1/beyond-domino-designer

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>Ah if you can blog about how to generate the Javadoc from inside Designer that would be great. At the moment I generate them in Eclipse from the ODP which is a bit of a faff!</p>
item.content:encoded: Ah if you can blog about how to generate the Javadoc from inside Designer that would be great. At the moment I generate them in Eclipse from the ODP which is a bit of a faff!

item.title: By: Paul Withers
item.dc:creator: Paul Withers
item.description: <p>That's a great tip, thanks for finding that out. I'm using JavaDocs more and more now I worked out how to easily build then from the NSF. With source control I can easily just build them directly to the documentation folder of my source control repository.</p>
item.content:encoded: That’s a great tip, thanks for finding that out. I’m using JavaDocs more and more now I worked out how to easily build then from the NSF. With source control I can easily just build them directly to the documentation folder of my source control repository.
